editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

TO which I an≈øwer, that they may be ≈øo taken, even by the warrant of God him≈øelfe: for in the 15. v. of the 11. c. of I≈øa. the ≈øelfe-≈øame miracle which Saint Iohn ≈øpeakes of at the effu≈øion of this ≈øixt vial, (to wit, the drying up of Euphrates) is plainly foretold: and that as a thing to be effected meerly for the Jewes ≈øakes at their generall redemption (which is there promi≈øed ver≈ø. 11, 12, 13. the words are the≈øe: And the Lord ≈øhall utterly de≈øtroy the tongue of the Egyptian Sea, and with his mighty wind ≈øhall he ≈øhake his hand over the 2 Sam. 10.16. Having then ≈øo good a te≈øtimony as this unaccompli≈øht prophe≈øie of I≈øaia is, to ju≈øtifie both the literall ≈øen≈øe of Euphrates, and the former opinion of the Kings of the Ea≈øt: Object. I marvell the more that ≈øo many learned Interpreters ≈øhould ≈øo ea≈øily reject it, unle≈ø≈øe (which could not well be) they had ≈øupported their owne allegoricall expo≈øition by a clearer and ≈øtronger evidence.

It were ≈øtrange (≈øaith Dr Major, pa. 475. of his expo≈øit. of the doubtfull texts of the catholike one) that ≈øuch a

An≈øw. But ≈øurely not ≈øo ≈øtrange as to heare ≈øuch words from a grave Divine. For from whence doth promotion come? If God doth all this, then well may the Jewes (how meane ≈øoever now) be called Kings in reference to that Day, in which they ≈øhall be ≈øuch (in which they ≈øhall reigne as Kings over other nations) and of the Ea≈øt too, in reference to the place from which they ≈øhall fir≈øt, and in greate≈øt number and ≈øtrength returne. For ≈øuch Kings of the Ea≈øt, as ≈øhall at that time be governours over tho≈øe countries, are nece≈ø≈øarily comprehended among≈øt the Kings of the earth, Rev. 16. and of the whole world mention'd in the 14. ver≈ø. as a≈ø≈øociates and partakers with the Dragon, Bea≈øt, and fal≈øe Prophet. And therefore I conclude againe, that this title may with farre more rea≈øon be attributed to the Jewes (who≈øe generall conver≈øion even the fore≈øaid p. 510. of his Exp. on the cath. epi≈øt. For although in this ≈øen≈øe no doubt can be made touching the name of Kings, becau≈øe it applyes the text to them that are properly and actually ≈øuch: yet why

Object. The next ≈øtumbling blocke that I meet with, is in Pareus, who tels us too, that it was the maine cau≈øe of his di≈ø≈øenting from the literall interpretation of this place. For, ≈øaith hee, either the ≈øixt plague is intimated by the≈øe words, which ≈øhew the drying up of Euphrates, or el≈øe here is no plague at all ≈øpoken of, ≈øeeing the following ver≈øes ≈øpeake not of the plague comprehended under this viall, but onely of the cour≈øe the Bea≈øt ≈øhall take for his defen≈øe again≈øt this plague. Whereby he ≈øeemes to mee to take it for granted, that if the drying up to Euphrates ≈øhould be under≈øtood literally, (as it ought to be in relation to the former expo≈øition of the Kings of the Ea≈øt) then it can nothing at all concerne the ruine and downefall of the Bea≈øt and fal≈øe Prophet.

An≈øw. 1 But what? Is there any thing too hard for the Lord? was his hand heavie upon all the Egyptians at the deliverance of the Jewes from the bondage of that Nation, and can hee not as well make the whole world to feele the weight of it, at their Redemption from all countryes? did he then harden Pharaohs heart to follow after his people, that he might be honour'd upon him, and upon all his Ho≈øt, and that the Egyptians might know that hee was the Lord: and can he not in the like manner, and for the like end, gather all Nations again≈øt them at their next returne? Surely, to deny this (and either this or the fore≈øaid argument mu≈øt be denyed) were to limit the power of God, and to ≈øhorten the arme of the Almighty, like tho≈øe who ≈øpake again≈øt God, and ≈øaid, Can God furni≈øh a table in the wilderne≈ø≈øe? behold, he ≈ømote the rocke, that the waters

Againe, Hath God ≈øaid, and ≈øhall he not doe it? or hath he ≈øpoken, and ≈øhall hee not make it good? hath he foretold the Jewes generall returne: the generall oppo≈øing of them by all Nations at their returne: the great and wondrous de≈øtruction, and generall di≈øtre≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe Nations: and the generall ≈øubjection of all the ≈øurviving Gentiles to the Jewes; hath hee, I ≈øay, by many Prophets, and for many yeares together, repeated all the≈øe things to his people (and that as plainly too, as their generall conver≈øion is revealed, to which yet mo≈øt Divines of note ≈øub≈øcribe) and ≈øhall they all come to nothing? Surely to affirme this (and who≈øoever allowes the fore≈øaid argument doth affirme it) were to make God a lier, while wee beleeve not his record. And therefore ≈øeeing God both can and will de i ‚Ä¢ er his people: and can and will Micah. 4 12, 13. P≈ø. 47. ‚Ä¢ 3. ≈øubdue all Nations to them at their deliverance; when ≈øhould we expect the accompli≈øhment of it, but under tho≈øe vials where we find an apparent allu≈øion to the Jewes Redemption, in the drying up of Euphrates: and an expre≈ø≈øe revelation both of an extraordinary gathering of the Kings of the Earth, and of the whole world to the battell of the great day of God Almighty, and al≈øo of an extraordinary de≈øtruction of them?

An≈øw. 7 To come then to a direct reply, I ≈øay, that Pareus ≈øuppo≈øeth much, but proves nothing. For fir≈øt
he takes it to be unque≈øtionable, that the plague of the ≈øixt vial, is intimated by the drying up of Euphrates: when as the abominable meanes, the devilli≈øh miracles, which ≈øhall be u≈øed for the gathering together of the Kings of the whole world, being a mo≈øt apparent taken of Gods fierce anger again≈øt them that ≈øhall be thus deluded, and a ≈øure fore-runner of an imminent temporall death on their bodies, and of an eternall on their ≈øoules; may, I thinke, well pa≈ø≈øe for the plague contained under this vial: e≈øpecially if wee con≈øider, that at the effu≈øion of the vials, there is fir≈øt mention of the mutation of the thing on which it is to be powred, and then of the hurt and dammage which men are to receive thereupon: to none of which the giving up of people to a reprobate mind (to their hearts lu≈øts, to vile affections) the ≈øending of them ≈øtrong delu≈øions, that they ≈øhall beleeve lies (that they ≈øhall even be deceived by the ≈øignes and lying wonders of Satans in≈øtruments) is any whit inferiour. Secondly, he ≈øuppo≈øeth, as I ≈øaid, that the drying up of Euphrates in a literall ≈øen≈øe, can no way ≈øet forward the de≈øtruction of the Bea≈øt and fal≈øe Prophet: and this ≈øuppo≈øition doth ≈øpring from another, which many interpreters deliver as an undeniable truth too, to wit, that the Bea≈øt and fal≈øe Prophet are the adequate object of all the vials; when as it is mo≈øt manife≈øt, that the la≈øt vial doth as immediately concerne the re≈øt of the world, as that part under the Bea≈øt: as well the Kings of the whole world, and their ≈øubjects, as the Bea≈øt and his. And very probable it is, that the ≈øecond, third, and fourth vials do belong to others al≈øo, be≈øides the wor≈øhippers of the Bea≈øt; and therefore though the fir≈øt and fifth vials be appropriated to the Bea≈øt & his dominions, yet I ≈øee
not why the extent of the≈øe ≈øhould be made the mea≈øure of any of the other vials, who≈øe effects are indefinitely revealed, rather than of the la≈øt vial, of which it's well knowne, that it ≈øhall light heavie on all the earth. For as I nothing doubt the literall accompli≈øhment of the drying up of Euphrates, ≈øo, if the≈øe words do ≈øet forth the plague of the ≈øixt vial, I beleeve al≈øo, that no other allegoricall and figurative ≈øen≈øe of the words is ≈øo likely to be here implyed with the literall, as that which MrComment. Now the≈øe frivolous, raw, and ra≈øh exceptions being thus remov'd, I come to that interpretation ≈øo commonly received, and ≈øo much preferred before the fore≈øaid ≈øen≈øe of Euphrates, and the Kings of the Ea≈øt, and it is this.

By the drying up of Euphrates (≈øay they) is ≈øet forth the decay of the riches, glory, and dominion of the Roman See, the profits which were wont to come from the Countries, and Kingdomes round about, being (for the mo≈øt part) taken away: by meanes whereof the Kings of the Ea≈øt, that is, the Chri≈øtian Kings and profe≈ø≈øors of the truth, whom God ≈øhall ≈øtirre up again≈øt her in the≈øe parts, ≈øhall have a notable advantage to bring her to ruine. And the ground of all this is that in the 17. chap. of the Rev. at the 16. ver≈ø. where 'tis ≈øaid, that the ten hornes (which are ten Kings, who were for a time to give their Kingdome unto the Bea≈øt, with whom in one houre

Secondly, ≈øeeing the ten Kings ≈øhall hate the whore, and make her de≈øolate, and naked, and eate, her fle≈øh, and burne her with fire: It followes,
